timeline.bodyText: What was the reason why instances of this are now required to be created instead of using the static methods ? To make testing easier ?
timeline.author: pleku

replies.bodyText:
The class may not be called Factory  as it has static methods only.
Factory is a generic pattern which is used via an instance to create something.
static methods may be considered as a factory methods but the methods only may be considered as factory methods (not a whole class).
The class which contains only static methods is a Helper but not a factory.
So the name was confusing from the very beginning.
Several reason apart of that:

It's possible to extend DeploymentConfigurationFactory now . (it's not possible to use the custom subclass but it's possible to allow to use it in the future: Lookup  can be used to get a DeploymentConfigurationFactory and then it will be possible to customize it via providing own config).
DeploymentConfigurationFactory extends AbstractConfigurationFactory . AbstractConfigurationFactory contains methods which are used in subclasses of AbstractConfigurationFactory: DefaultApplicationConfigurationFactory is a real factory whose instance is used to create an ApplicationConfiguration and the AbstractConfigurationFactory::getConfigParametersUsingTokenData  method has to be an instance method ( so this method may not be used in the static  method as is. I would have been make an instance of DeploymentConfigurationFactory to use it which is absolutely ugly).
Technically  DeploymentConfigurationFactory  is done consistently now with DefaultApplicationConfigurationFactory .
Testing became much easier with correctly used patterns.
replies.author: denis-anisimov

replies.bodyText:
I'm not sure whether I get your concern right.....
But I don't like isOwnProperty call here either. The implementation is fragile indeed.
But fragility is non removable. It comes from the essence of configuration design.
DeploymentConfiguration  is an interface but it has a mixture of API and implementation methods.
E.g. isProductionMode is API method.
getStringProperty is an implementation method which should have been defined in an abstract class to reuse it in subclasses.
But we have what we have:

isProductionMode  whose value technically is based on SERVLET_PARAMETER_PRODUCTION_MODE property and getStringProperty is used to get the property value. BUT  getStringProperty doesn't have to be respected in isProductionMode  implementation since it's a totally different method. isProductionMode  may be implemented in one way and getStringProperty for SERVLET_PARAMETER_PRODUCTION_MODE  in another way. That's the consequence of the "API" design.
As a result there are 4 cases to consider for DeploymentConfiguration:  isProductionMode  impl, SERVLET_PARAMETER_PRODUCTION_MODE  property value , isProductionMode  impl for parent ApplicationConfiguration and SERVLET_PARAMETER_PRODUCTION_MODE  property value for parent ApplicationConfiguration.

DeploymentConfiguration and ApplicationConfiguration properties are merged because DeploymentConfiguration should contain properties from the parent config as well.
But then getApplicationProperty (and getStringProperty  which is based on this method) MAY NOT be used to implement isProduction: because getApplicationProperty asks for DeploymentConfiguration first and then it asks for  ApplicationConfiguration property.
As a result ApplicationConfiguration::isProductionMode is ignored in this case.
So only "implementation level" of the configuration design based on properties works. And this is wrong.
That's why I had to add isOwnProperty.
I can use another method for isProductionMode  implementation instead getBooleanProperty : yes.
But then I will have to introduce:

override for getBooleanProperty() based on override for getStringProperty
override for getStringProperty() : since the current impl may not be used as is ( described above why)
override for getApplicationProperty which doesn't take into account parent properties.

So instead of one  isOwnProperty there will be 3 new methods.
And what's worst here: if you add one more property to the config (a new API method) then you won't be able to get which getBooleanProperty/ getStringProperty/ getApplicationProperty to use: there will be couple of methods for every name.
I consider this as even more fragile : 3 additional methods which is too easy to mix up with the method having the same name.
I don't have strong opinion on this. I've decided that is isOwnProperty introduces less problems comparing to any other approach which I had as optional.
If you see the good proper way to solve this issue then I will be happy to apply it here.
replies.author: denis-anisimov

replies.bodyText:
I agree with your comments and I don't have a flawless solution to offer either.
One option, that we have sometimes opted for, would be to have a test that checks whether certain types of / named methods in e.g. interface DeploymentConfiguration are overridden in the child class PropertyDeploymentConfiguration, to avoid bugs that someone adds a new method with default implementation to the interface / abstract child class but not the PropertyDeploymentConfiguration.
I don't know how likely it is that this test will catch a bug in reality.
replies.author: pleku

replies.bodyText:
There are many other ways to make the implementation invalid because of fragility.
In fact the default impl in the DeploymentConfiguration is not an issue until there is no the same method in the parent ApplicationConfiguration.
So default impl should be checked in the AbstractConfiguration . But then again it's possible to add methods with the same name into  DeploymentConfiguration and ApplicationConfiguration apart of AbstractConfiguration.
I think it's just not possible to catch all possible cases to make incorrect implementation so it's not worth to
